The stock market sell-off has intensified, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 both down over 10% from their recent highs and the Nasdaq Composite down over 20% as of this writing-- putting the growth-heavy index in a bear market.  In fact, fast-food giant McDonald's (NYSE: MCD) hit an all-time high in March and is up slightly year-to-date at the time of this writing.  Here's why the Dow Jones component is well positioned to endure tariffs and why the dividend stock could be worth buying now.
McDonald's (MCD) closed at $299.89 in the latest trading session, marking a -0.07% move from the prior day.
While the Dow Jones represents industry leaders, not every stock in the index is a safe bet. Some are facing headwinds like declining demand, rising costs, or disruptive new competitors.
Store expansion and a comeback of the China market is the hope; tariff backlash could shutter that.
LOCO's ability to manage costs, adapt to evolving consumer preferences, and maintain a differentiated brand identity should support growth.
